trial_identification.studytitle: Betadine Trial -Does use of Betadine solution to wound prior to closure of skin at caesarean section affect wound healing and or infection after caesarean section
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Does use of Betadine solution to wound prior to closure of skin at caesarean section affect wound healing and or infection after caesarean section

conditions.healthcondition: Post caesarean section wound healing and sepsis

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Studies of infection and infectious agents

interventions.interventions: prior to closure of skin at caesarean section women will be randomised to betadine or no betadine soak of the wound. 20 mls of betadine solution is poured onto the incision site prior to skin closure and skin closed as normal practice within 30 seconds.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Wound infection within 6 weeks of delivery - this will be by phone contact and or a letter - currently this is the routine practice by the infection control unit for all c/sections. Chart audit if admitted to hospital

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Wound healing -phone interview or lettter and chart audit if admitted to hospital

trial_design.concealment: stratified by elective c/section or c/section in labour consecutively numbered opaque envelopes containing the allocation will be in theatre and will only be opened immediately prior to skin closure
trial_design.sequence: random number table with block of 10

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Dept of obstetrics chelmsford Avenue Ipswich Hospital Ipswich qld 4305

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Dept of obstetrics chelsford Avenue Ipswich Qld 4305

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Infection after c/section is a concern for women and health workers. Prophylactic antibiotics are used to prevent infection but some will still develop the complication. betadine is routinely used for skin preparation prior to c/section. It is believed that its use again immediately prior to skin closure may further reduce the infection rate. This is an open randomsied controlled trial. Hospital infection control dept routinely make contact with all c/section women. This source will be used to gather information on women who develop any problem with ht ewound. They routinely provide consent to be contacted for this purpose and therefore no additional consent will be required .

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Darling Downs and West Morton health Service district DWMHSD HREC
ethicscommitee.ethicaddress: The Park - centre for mental health Ellerton Road Wacol Qld 4074
